question_text: How do the sulphur-free nature and paraffinic composition of carbon-neutral drop-in fuels like HVO and e-diesel enable efficient exhaust aftertreatment technologies and contribute to emission reductions in marine diesel engines, based on the provided paper content?
standard_answer: The paper states that carbon-neutral fuels are typically sulphur-free, which enables negligible SOx emissions and facilitates the use of efficient exhaust aftertreatment technologies like particle filtration. This sulphur-free characteristic eliminates one of the major barriers to implementing advanced emission control systems in marine engines. Additionally, the paper notes that HVO consists of paraffins (alkanes) and has a very high cetane number and high quality sufficient for road transport, with similar paraffinic fuels produced through biomass gasification followed by Fischer-Tropsch liquefaction to produce BTL fuel. The combination of these properties in carbon-neutral drop-in fuels allows for effective emission control while maintaining compatibility with existing marine engine infrastructure, supporting the transition toward near-zero emission shipping through the integration of fuel properties and aftertreatment technologies.
